context: [8] However, inHolophaga foetida, Sporobacter termitidis, and Sporobacterium olearium, the O demethylation of methoxylated aromatic compounds did not strictly depend on sulfide (or MT) as methyl group acceptor. [9] O demethylation in strain SA2 appeared to be strictly sulfide dependent , but unfortunately this strain was lost, which made a complete description of the isolate impossible. [1] The present study reports on the impact of methoxylated aromatic compounds on the production of volatile organic sulfur compounds (VOSC) in freshwater sediments. [2] Further, the isolation of an obligately anaerobic bacterium which produces DMS and MT during growth on methoxylated aromatic compounds in sulfide-reduced mineral media is described. [3] O demethylation of methoxylated aromatic compounds by our isolate appears to be strictly sulfide dependent. [1] Source of inoculum.Sediment samples were collected from a eutrophic freshwater pond (campus of the Dekkerswald Institute, Nijmegen, The Netherlands). [2] The sediment samples were taken by suction in anaerobic bottles as described by Lomans et al. .

llm_generation.summary: In this context, methylsulfanylmethane (MT) is mentioned in relation to the O demethylation of methoxylated aromatic compounds by certain anaerobic bacteria. The study indicates that the demethylation process is dependent on sulfide, which suggests a biochemical interaction between MT and aromatic compounds. However, the specifics of this relationship are not deeply explored, focusing instead on the broader implications of volatile organic sulfur compounds (VOSC) production in freshwater sediments.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 3 reflects a moderate relevance, as methylsulfanylmethane is involved in the biochemical process related to the demethylation of aromatic compounds, indicating some interaction. However, the details of their relationship are not extensively discussed.
